title: Why do people care so much if someone is toxic?

It's not about the competitive aspect, it's about showing respect to your fellow human beings.  Be it sports or knitting, if someone can't show respect to their fellow people they shouldn't be allowed to participate.

And it's true there's no equivalent to a mute button IRL, but as with most things we have a specific course of action in place to remove the problem person.  Go up to the front desk and tell them someone is causing a disturbance, and they will have security remove the person from the theater.

> [{quoted}](name=Pseudojene,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=cEdTNx0T,comment-id=00050000,timestamp=2018-08-09T00:15:29.504+0000)

You're using competition to justify perhaps trash talking. Fine, but trash talking ain't toxicity. No one on the pitch, court, or field ever someone to commit suicide without some sort of malice, and usually something like that would end up in a physical alteration but it wouldn't ever be deemed acceptable. And now in most competitive sports, in the heat of the moment, when trash talking escalates with officials or refs, ya can get punished.

Just because the internet affords distance between individuals, it's not a cart blanche to do as one wishes and say as one wishes without some sort of cause and effect.  

Moreover in sports you have the ability to take the measure of someone and what they say. You can interpret by tone. That's why speech is so powerful. Is it said playfully? Sarcastically? Out of sheer competitive drive? Malice? Bad intent? It's much harder to tell these things when it's just by text, and thus why often people take things at face value online, and it's not unreasonble to do so when someone takes 20 chat lines to rage either at teammates, opponents, Riot or both.

I'll guarantee the way you write an email to a friend is a lot different than the way you speak to them, even if they might know your mannerisms. I don't think it's unreasonable to expect people to think before they type something out.

And it's not even about people being too sensitive. It's about people literally being masochists. Riot clearly puts a carrot AND stick in front of players. They know X will get them a carrot and Y gets the stick. Yet, they do Y, get the stick, often repeatedly, and then complain about getting hit bout on the noggin.

"Oh, I upset you by not playing the way you want?" Suck it up.

Eh. I don't particularity care about one or the other. Just that his argument can also applied to him.

I will say your side seems to be a bit of an escalation though.

Flame should be dealt with by muting. Reporting is an escalation.

If he "sucked it up" then he never would have flamed someone to begin with. His argument is non existent if he didn't get upset.

Applies for unintentional and intentional "feeding".
If it is unintentional, as most likely will be, then you are just getting upset at someone who is already angry at themselves.
If it is intentional, then you are Judy playing into the trolls hands.

> If he "sucked it up" then he never would have flamed someone to begin with. His argument is non existent if he didn't get upset.

If either of you actually "sucked it up", neither of you would be upset. I find it funny too because "YOUR argument is non existent if YOU don't get upset".

Here, let me sequence the events.

1. X isn't having a great game.

2. Y is upset and begins to flame.

3. W,V, X, Z are annoyed(not upset) at the flaming.

4. W,V,X,Z (either alone or in combination) report

If 2 never happened then 3, and 4 don't happen either. (my argument)

If 3 didn't happen, then 4 doesn't happen. (his argument).

Both are true, but it starts at 2 earliest.

Where did you learn to count?

It starts at 1. If 1 doesn't happen, 2,3, and 4 don't happen!

Middle ground solves all the numbers.
1. X needs to reassure the team that their bad play is not intentional.
2. Y doesn't flame despite being upset.
3. W,V,X,Z mute the flaming.

Because reassuring always stops the flaming.  /s

I stand by my sequence.

Your sequence wasn't the issue. It was your counting skills.

> Both are true, but it starts at 2 earliest.

1 definitely comes before 2 in my language.

But 2 is the first step that can actually be prevented consistently.

If we could choose to have bad games or not (trolls/inters aside) most people would choose to never have a bad game.

> But 2 is the first step that can actually be prevented consistently.

Now you are adding extra stipulations and changing the topic. Even then, 1 is capable of being prevented consistently. (Depends on your definition of consistent.)

> If we could choose to have bad games or not (trolls/inters aside) most people would choose to never have a bad game.

You make league sound like a game of chance rather than skill.

Losing doesn't mean you played bad. It means the other team played better.

Funnily, from my personal experience, people complain about my cs being too much rather than too little.

EDIT: hit the reply limit. Too much to sift through. Thanks for talking with me.

There is an element of luck to it, especially in lower elo. There is always a chance of going against someone who is just flat out better than you. They can be farming under tower to be safe and someone will most likely still complain about your low cs score.

People care because it tends to tilt their teammates. I've seen it happen a lot. I try to get my teammates to ignore the toxicity and just keep their heads in the game but toxicity gets to lots of people. 

When people get tilted, they play worse. When someone is toxic and trying to spread the tilt, it makes my team lose as a whole because the teamwork is not there anymore.

When the teamwork isn't there anymore, we usually lose, which means I just wasted time in a game not having fun because someone was toxic and felt like being a jackass to their own teammate.

It's not about getting someone reported, it's about ensuring this game is still fun to play.
Getting the report is learning.
